DOCNAME: CASE OF SOLAKOV v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
CONCLUSION: No violation of Art. 6-1;No violation of Art. 6-3-d
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , who had lived for a while in GPE , was suspected of drug trafficking and a warrant for his arrest was issued by GPE police in DATE .

CARDINAL . Following the request of GPE authorities , on DATE the public prosecutor asked ORG to institute a preliminary investigation against the applicant on charges that DATE and DATE he had smuggled QUANTITY of drugs from GPE and the Former GPE to GPE and that for that purpose had set up a drug - trafficking network involving also his son , who lives in GPE . The prosecution ’s request set out the names of the persons involved and against whom criminal proceedings were pending or completed in GPE and asked for their questioning .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge opened a criminal investigation against the applicant , decided to hear the witnesses proposed by the prosecution and detained the applicant on remand .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge asked ORG to contact the GPE government and to request their assistance in the hearing of some witnesses in their country . On DATE ORG addressed the request to GPE embassy .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE embassy was informed by the investigating judge of the investigation pending against the applicant . The notice contained the names of the witnesses to be examined in GPE and a list of CARDINAL questions to be put to them .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyer was informed that the investigating judge would go to GPE DATE and was summoned to the hearing .

CARDINAL . On DATE the lawyer was denied a visa for GPE on the ground that he had not produced all the relevant documents required . The GPE embassy informed him that it would review his application for a visa provided that he submitted a certificate of his working position , income , and seniority and evidence that he owned real estate and had family ties in the Former GPE . The lawyer never reapplied for a visa . On DATE the applicant withdrew his power of attorney .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appointed another lawyer , who , on DATE , was summoned to attend the hearing of witnesses in GPE , scheduled for DATE . On the summons , the lawyer placed his signature in the space provided for the bailiff ’s signature and the bailiff placed his signature in the space provided for the lawyer ’s signature .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was questioned . He stated that he had been informed by the investigating judge that witnesses would be heard in GPE . He had contacted his second lawyer and left to him the decision whether or not to attend the hearing . He further stated that the expenses for the trip would not be a problem as he had sufficient funds to cover them .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigating judge informed the GPE embassy in the Former GPE that on DATE the applicant ’s first lawyer had been summoned to attend the questioning of the witnesses in GPE and that the applicant ’s second lawyer had declared that there was no need to attend the questioning and that he had insufficient funds to meet the travel expenses .

CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE , CARDINAL witnesses were heard by the investigating judge in the presence of the public prosecutor and the court interpreter . Their testimonies were recorded . The witnesses were involved in the drug - trafficking network organised by the applicant , and they were all serving prison sentences in GPE for drug trafficking .

CARDINAL . According to the witnesses , who were under oath and were heard separately , it was the applicant who had set up the entire network and who had organised the smuggling into GPE and the re - sale there of QUANTITY of drugs . The applicant had contacts in GPE , from where he would smuggle the drugs into the Former GPE . He would then arrange for them to be smuggled into GPE . Some of the witnesses stated that they had smuggled the drugs in a plaster - cast which the applicant would wrap around one of their legs , as though it were broken . On their arrival in GPE they would hand over the drugs to the applicant ’s son in return for payment . Some of the witnesses stated that they had had an agreement with the applicant and his son for drug dealing and had been supplied with the drugs in the applicant ’s and his son ’s house .

CARDINAL . Two of the witnesses who had travelled to GPE on separate occasions gave evidence that they had been taken into Mr PERSON flat in GPE , where Mr PERSON and the applicant had wrapped plasters with drugs around one of the ORG legs . None of the witnesses made any statement regarding Mr PERSON

CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecutor indicted the applicant with drug trafficking from GPE and the Former GPE to GPE and with setting up an international network for that purpose . The ORG statements were included in the indictment .
On DATE the applicant was released .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant made a submission to ORG that there was no case to answer as there was no convincing evidence against him . In particular , the indictment was predominantly based on the testimonies of the witnesses who were serving prison sentences in GPE and who had not been cross - examined by the defence . The applicant argued that the witnesses had a deal with GPE authorities to have their sentences reduced in exchange for their cooperation . On the one hand , since they had already been convicted in GPE , the witnesses were aware that they would not risk anything if they gave false evidence , as they could not be prosecuted for drug trafficking under the law of the Former GPE . On the other hand , if they modified their testimonies , they ran the risk of losing all the benefits which had been agreed upon by the authorities .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court held that on the basis of all the evidence in the case there was a reasonable suspicion that the applicant might have committed the offence with which he had been charged and refused to terminate the criminal proceedings against him .

CARDINAL . On DATE a hearing was held before ORG . On DATE a second hearing was held . The applicant claimed to be innocent and stated that he had not travelled to GPE because he knew that it might be dangerous for him .

Photographs showing the plaster - cast , belonging to a person involved in the drug dealing with the applicant , in which drugs had been found , photographs of the witnesses , reports on the search of the applicant ’s son ’s and another witness ’s flat where some drugs had been found and the reports on the investigation in connection with the applicant ’s son and his pre - trial detention were , inter alia , examined .
CARDINAL . The applicant complained that he had been unable to cross - examine the witnesses . He also objected to their statements being read out in open court .

The court decided to read out in open court the statements of the witnesses examined in GPE , because “ to secure the attendance of the witnesses is extremely difficult and there are also other important reasons ” .

The applicant challenged the ORG statements without pointing out concretely why they should not be considered trustworthy , or specifying the questions that he would have liked to be put to the witnesses .
CARDINAL . At the hearing of CARDINAL DATE the applicant requested that CARDINAL additional witnesses for the defence be examined . The record of the hearing states as follows :

“ ... the applicant ’s lawyer asked the court to gather information about Mr PERSON , in particular regarding his place of residence , whether Mr PERSON was charged with being one of the co - organisers [ of the drug trafficking ] with the accused , [ and if so ] to obtain his case file , and to call him as a witness .

He also called the witness , Mr PERSON , from the village of GPE , GPE , to give evidence on whether he knew the accused and Mr PERSON , whether he had ever been in Mr PERSON ’s flat with the accused , whether he knew if the accused had been supplied with drugs ( amphetamines ) , whether he knew some of the prosecution witnesses , etc . ... ”
ORG refused the motion on the ground that “ the court [ had ] sufficient evidence before it to reach its verdict ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE the municipal court found the applicant guilty of drug trafficking within the meaning of LAW of LAW and sentenced him to DATE imprisonment . The court dismissed the applicant ’s objection that there had been a breach of his right of defence in that he had been unable to cross - examine the witnesses , on the ground that it had been impossible to summon them . It considered the ORG statements reliable , since they had had no opportunity to make a deal with the public prosecutor of the Former GPE to have their sentences in GPE reduced in exchange for giving evidence against the applicant . The court further observed that all the witnesses had recognised the applicant on a photo and that , although each of them had been heard separately by the investigating judge in the presence of the public prosecutor , their statements were consistent and precise . The court also had regard to the applicant ’s testimony .

CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecutor submitted an appeal to ORG суд ) requesting an increase of the sentence in view of the nature of the offence committed , the degree of danger to the public , the fact that it concerned organised crime at international level and the fact that the applicant was a habitual offender .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant also filed an appeal with ORG , complaining , inter alia , that the lower court had infringed LAW , as it had reached its verdict only on the basis of the statements of witnesses whom he had not cross - examined . The applicant further complained about the court ’s refusal to hear CARDINAL additional witnesses on his behalf .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal on the ground that ORG had acted in accordance with LAW , which stated that witnesses might be heard in the absence of the accused or his lawyer if there was a valid reason making it impossible or extremely difficult to do otherwise ( see “ Relevant domestic law and practice ” below ) .

The court found that the lower court had given a reasoned explanation why it was extremely difficult to cross - examine those witnesses at the public hearing . They had been heard only by the investigating judge and the public prosecutor , but the legal representatives of the applicant had been duly summoned for the examination of the witnesses and , therefore , had had a sufficient opportunity to attend the ORG questioning .

It held that the statements were consistent and logical and were corroborated by each other and by other evidence such as the reports from the searches carried out in the flat of the applicant ’s son and of another witness . It also held that the CARDINAL witnesses called by the defence were not relevant as they would not have contributed much to the establishment of the truth .
The court granted the public prosecutor ’s appeal and increased the applicant ’s sentence to DATE imprisonment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed an appeal on points of law ( Барање за вонредно преиспитување на правосилна одлука ) with ORG ( Врховен суд ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal on points of law on the grounds that the investigating judge had acted within his competence when he decided to interrogate the witnesses in GPE and that the applicant and his lawyers had been given an opportunity to attend the hearing . Furthermore , ORG held that it would have been impossible to have the witnesses heard at the public hearing , as they were serving a prison sentence abroad . Consequently , in accordance with the rules of LAW there were sufficient reasons to justify the statements being read out at the public hearing .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s son declared before a notary that his father had had nothing to do with drug trafficking . Another person also declared before a public notary that the applicant had been engaged in trade with spare parts for motor vehicles .
On DATE the applicant applied to ORG to have his case reopened on the basis of those declarations . His application was dismissed on DATE . On DATE that decision was upheld by ORG .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL , inter alia , provides that a bench of CARDINAL judges of the first - instance court shall decide on appeals lodged against the decisions of the investigating judge .
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL , inter alia , provides that a person shall have the right to appeal against the decisions of the investigating judge .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § § CARDINAL and CARDINAL provides that the president of the court may officially appoint a lawyer for a person who is detained pending trial .

CARDINAL . Under Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL a lawyer has the right to consult all the documents in the case file from DATE the prosecution authorities request the investigating judge to open a preliminary investigation . A defendant enjoys that right from DATE he has been questioned by the investigating judge .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides that the parties may ask the investigating judge to undertake different actions in the course of the investigation .
LAW , DATE and CARDINAL reads as follows :

“ CARDINAL . NORP The prosecution , the defendant and the defendant ’s lawyer shall have the right to be present when an investigating judge is examining a witness who will not be heard at a public hearing ...

CARDINAL . When the prosecution , the defendant and the defendant ’s lawyer are entitled to be present ... at an interrogation of a witness by an investigating judge , they shall be informed of the time and place of ... the interrogation . If the defendant has been represented by a lawyer the investigating judge shall only inform the lawyer .
CARDINAL . Persons present at the interrogation of a witness may ask the investigating judge to put questions to him ... ”
Article QUANTITY , CARDINAL and CARDINAL reads as follows :

“ CARDINAL . When an allegation is based on a statement of a person , that person shall be heard at a public hearing . The right to cross - examine him shall not be lost because the transcript of his statement is read out , or because he has already given a written statement .
CARDINAL . As an exception ... a bench of judges may decide to read out the transcript of the witness ’s statement ... if :
( i ) the person concerned has died , is mentally ill , can not be found , or if his attendance is impossible because of old age , illness or any other important reason .
CARDINAL . In the records of the public hearing , the court shall state the reasons why the transcript of the witness ’s statement is read out and whether the witness ... took an oath . ”

As a matter of court practice , the fact that a witness is abroad has been considered as an “ important reason ” within the meaning of LAW ( i ) of the LAW , as the court may have no effective means of securing his attendance at the public hearing .
Article CARDINAL provides that where necessary the court may , at its own discretion , decide to hear a tape - recording of the witness ’s statement instead of relying solely on the transcript .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § § CARDINAL and CARDINAL reads as follows :
“ CARDINAL . The parties shall have the right to call a witness ... or other evidence at the hearing even after the case is listed for a hearing .
CARDINAL . NORP If the President of the ORG dismisses the request to call fresh evidence , the parties shall have the right to call the evidence at the public hearing . ”

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides that criminal proceedings may be reopened if , inter alia , a new fact or new evidence is adduced or called before the court , which may prove the convicted person ’s innocence or militate for the reduction of his sentence .
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL reads as follows :

“ A defendant who has been convicted and sentenced to imprisonment or to youth custody by a binding judgment shall have the right to lodge an appeal on points of law in the cases set forth in this Code . ”
Article CARDINAL reads as follows :
“ ORG shall have jurisdiction to deal with such appeals . ”
Article CARDINAL taken in conjunction with Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL lays down that such appeals may be lodged on the ground that the courts have erred in law .

Article CARDINAL taken in conjunction with Article CARDINAL provides that when the ORG grants the appeal on points of law it may substitute its own verdict or quash the decisions of the lower courts and remit the case to them , or declare that the lower courts erred in law .
